Award.AwardTitle: Iowa EPSCoR: Harnessing Energy Flows in the Biosphere to Build Sustainable Energy Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: EPS-1101284

Proposal Title: Iowa EPSCoR: Harnessing Energy Flows in the Biosphere to Build Sustainable Energy Systems

Institution: Iowa State University

This Research Infrastructure Improvement project seeks to expand the research capacity within the state to support a transition in energy supply from subsurface fossil energy stores to renewable energy flows at or near the earth?s surface. The research program is organized into four platforms in renewable energy, each of which consists of several research foci (or planks) which are detailed below. The project seeks to examine energy flows and processes from a holistic systems perspective that considers technical, economic, social, and environmental constraints and impacts. This comprehensive program will enable innovative research, strengthen energy-related education, train a ?clean-tech? workforce, and engage diverse communities in implementing environmentally and economically sustainable solutions to the growing energy challenges facing Iowa and the U.S. The project brings together research universities, 2- and 4-year colleges, the private sector, and local government agencies (Iowa Power Fund, Iowa Office of Energy Independence), to address key issues related to renewable energy research, education, and workforce development in the state.

Intellectual Merit
This proposal seeks to significantly enhance the research competitiveness of Iowa through a comprehensive, multi-faceted research program in renewable energy and energy efficiency. The program builds upon existing strengths of Iowa in the areas of bioenergy and wind energy while including highly complementary components in the areas of energy efficiency and energy policy. The program seeks to change the energy landscape across Iowa by improving the energy balance while mitigating environmental concerns and positioning citizens to compete more effectively in a global economy.

Broader Impacts
An overarching goal of this project is to translate the knowledge gained in the research platforms into specific actions that can increase the participation of under-represented minorities in STEM fields. IA EPSCoR proposes the creation of the Future Leaders in Advancing Renewable Energy (FLARE) Institute to lead the implementation of strategic broader impacts activities. Modeled after the Iowa?s NSF I3 program, Strengthening the Professoriate at ISU, the FLARE Institute will be a state-wide organization supporting the human infrastructure development needed to accelerate Iowa?s transition to a green economy. Critical to this goal are strategies to broaden the participation of women, underrepresented minorities, and first-generation college students in the STEM fields, prepare a workforce that can meet the demands of Iowa?s emerging green economy, and create a community of scholars who integrate broader impacts into their research efforts in all fields. Accordingly, the FLARE Institute will address key deficiencies in state-wide infrastructure by integrating broader impacts through all elements of activities leveraged by IA EPSCoR, thereby having a far greater state-wide impact than any individual program could achieve on its own.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2017 Iowa NSF EPSCoR Project Outcomes Report

October 2017

The Iowa NSF EPSCoR project ran from 2011 – 2017 and was a joint effort by Iowa’s Regent universities (the University of Iowa, University of Northern Iowa, and Iowa State University) and led by Iowa State University. The goal of the $20 million grant from the National Science Foundation was to build Iowa’s research capacity in renewable energy and energy efficiency. The Iowa Power Fund, a state program supporting energy innovation and independence, provided an additional $2 million for infrastructure development. 

Nearly 800 faculty, staff, and students (38% female and 10% underrepresented minorities) participated in the four research platforms of BioEnergy, Wind Energy, Energy Utilization, and Energy Policy, as well as the Broader Impacts platform. Some of the major accomplishments are summarized below.

The Bioenergy platform developed three Bioenergy Agro-Ecosystem Research (BAER) sites located near the three Iowa Regent universities which has enabled long-term research studies in the area of biomass for energy harvesting. One promising energy crop, Miscanthus, has been incorporated into an on-going collaboration between Iowa State, University of Iowa, and several industrial partners in a project entitled the Long-term Assessment of Miscanthus Productivity and Sustainability (LAMPS). The Bioenergy platform has also developed an open source thermochemical conversion software that can be used to design and optimize thermochemical reactors. This code has been validated and disseminated and is now freely available for download from the web.

The Wind Energy platform has developed two highly instrumented tall towers, one located within an operating wind farm and one onside a wind farm, to enable long-term studies of the effect wind turbines have on wake speed, turbulence, wake interactions, and crop cover at the base of the wind turbines. The towers are 120 m high and will provide unique data that have never before been recorded. A web-based wind energy decision support system that aids in both state-level and local-level wind turbine siting has been developed and has led to greater understanding of land cover’s effect on wind power potential. A new model of turbine blade damage from lightning has been developed and shows the interaction between a lightning channel and a composite structure of a damaged blade. A novel manufacturing and repair processes involving laser cutting, fusion, and peening were developed to reduce the cost of turbine blade repair. A reliability analysis of turbine blade fatigue, drivetrain dynamics, and gearbox failure, has resulted in better understanding of design optimization variables and cost constraints to wind turbine life cycle analysis.

The Energy Utilization platform used three communities within Iowa to develop intervention strategies through a social marketing campaign to decrease community-level energy consumption. A previous student-designed solar home was installed at Honey Creek State Park as the activities center, and then fully instrumented so visitors can interact with the home to observed energy efficiency strategies in action. The Energy Utilization platform also developed a mobile trailer to test various building materials at locations throughout Iowa. An exhibit introducing Iowa renewable energy sources and energy efficiency strategies was also developed for the University of Iowa Mobile Museum, and it traveled throughout the state educating Iowans in energy utilization.

The Energy Policy platform explored how economists and engineers can collaborate on energy policy and advise policy makers on renewable energy and energy efficiency issues. It was determined that policy can be as important as technology development in advancing the commercialization of renewable energy, and poorly crafted policy can lead to unintended consequences.

The Broader Impacts platform focused on efforts to 1) prepare a better prepared workforce in energy and related areas; 2) broaden the participation of women, underrepresented minorities, and first-generation college students in the STEM pipeline and; 3) create a community of scholars who integrate broader impacts into their research effort. Workforce development activities focused on K-12 student and teacher training, as well as new course development and revision in Iowa‘s universities. Faculty development activities were also emphasized, and a checklist was incorporated into the ISU Grants Hub best practices to ensure faculty incorporate well-planned broader impacts activities into their research programs and proposals. As part of the diversity efforts, the University of Iowa leveraged NSF EPSCoR activities to establish the Sloan Center for Exemplary Mentoring to study the experiences of underrepresented minority graduate students in STEM fields.

All of the research and broader impact activities of the Iowa NSF EPSCoR project were shared through a project newsletter, website, and social media accounts to keep participants, partners, industry, supporters, government officials, and the public informed of the program’s research, events, successes, and impact. Many summaries can be found at http://www.iowaepscor.org/.
